channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Gerry Adams held over widow's murder
item.description: Northern Ireland politician Gerry Adams, leader of Sinn Fein, is arrested by police over the 1972 IRA murder of mother-of-10 Jean McConville.

item.title: Deadly attack at Chinese station
item.description: A bomb and knife attack at a railway station in China's Xinjiang region leaves three dead and 79 others wounded, state media say.

item.title: Computer glitch causes airport delays
item.description: Passengers are facing disruption at UK airports across the country after an IT glitch resulted in lengthy queues forming at immigration desks.

item.title: Kiev 'helpless' in east Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine's acting President Olexander Turchynov admits his forces are helpless to quell unrest driven by pro-Russia activists in parts of the east.

item.title: Actor Bob Hoskins dies aged 71
item.description: British actor Bob Hoskins, best known for films such as Who Framed Roger Rabbit and The Long Good Friday, dies of pneumonia at the age of 71.

item.title: Derailed train bursts into flames
item.description: A train derails and catches fire in the US state of Virginia, forcing the evacuation of hundreds from nearby buildings.

item.title: Botched US execution sparks review
item.description: The governor of the US state of Oklahoma orders a "full review" of the state's execution procedures following a botched execution.

item.title: Nigeria march over girls' abductions
item.description: Women in Nigeria march to demand that more be done to secure the release of 230 schoolgirls abducted by militants two weeks ago.

item.title: Warnings on S Korea ferry 'ignored'
item.description: The owner of the sunken South Korean ferry ignored a captain's warnings about the ship's stability, prosecutors say, as two company officials are detained.

item.title: Iraqi vote held in security lockdown
item.description: Iraq holds its first parliamentary vote since the withdrawal of US troops three years ago, as at least 14 people are killed in sporadic violence.

item.title: Children 'killed in Aleppo strike'
item.description: An air strike by Syrian government forces hits a school in Aleppo and kills at least 18 people, including 10 children, activists say.

item.title: Jeremy Paxman to quit Newsnight
item.description: Jeremy Paxman announces he is quitting BBC Two's Newsnight after 25 years at the helm, saying he would "like to go to bed at much the same time as most people".

item.title: VIDEO: Obituary: Bob Hoskins
item.description: British actor Bob Hoskins, who was best known for roles in The Long Good Friday and Who Framed Roger Rabbit, has died of pneumonia at the age of 71.

item.title: VIDEO: Making music the old way
item.description: Clare Salaman plays a number of instruments that date back to medieval times and founded The Society of Strange and Ancient Instruments.

item.title: VIDEO: Could wearable tech boost our output?
item.description: A study carried out by Goldsmiths, University of London found that some wearable technology could boost productivity by 8%.

item.title: VIDEO: One-minute World News
item.description: Watch the latest news summary from BBC World News. International news updated 24 hours a day.

item.title: VIDEO: 100 days to demolish 1,000 chimneys
item.description: Authorities in north China's Hebei province start demolishing hundreds of chimneys and coal-fired boilers in an effort to tackle air pollution.

item.title: VIDEO: Polish FM on solving Ukraine crisis
item.description: Polish Foreign Minister Radek Sikorski, who has played a leading role in European diplomacy in the Ukraine crisis, has called for unity within the EU against Russian efforts to destabilise Ukraine.

item.title: VIDEO: Sao Paulo's squatter communities
item.description: Brazil's wealth has grown in the past decade but deep inequalities remain, nowhere more so than the country's biggest city of Sao Paulo.

item.title: VIDEO: Building a refugee camp from scratch
item.description: As a huge new refugee camp for Syrians opens in Jordan, the BBC's Yolande Knell looks at how the facility was planned from scratch.

item.title: Prince Harry and Cressida split up
item.description: Prince Harry and his girlfriend Cressida Bonas have broken up after two years together, with the split said to be "amicable".

item.title: Outdoor grills banned in Beijing
item.description: The authorities in Beijing are banning popular outdoor grills amid fears of rising pollution.

item.title: US Fed continues to shrink stimulus
item.description: The US Federal Reserve announces a further slowdown of its stimulus efforts, trimming its monthly bond-purchases by $10bn.

item.title: Facebook to place ads in other apps
item.description: Facebook announces its own mobile ad network to place adverts inside third-party apps, putting it into competition with Google and Apple.

item.title: Google halts student Gmail scans
item.description: Google stops scanning millions of Gmail accounts linked to an education scheme after reports this might have breached a US privacy law.

item.title: 'Pay-by-size' for films in future
item.description: The future of film releases will radically change in future as viewers pay according to the size of their screen, Dreamworks Animation's boss says.

item.title: Patrick Stewart to return to TV
item.description: Sir Patrick Stewart is to star in a new comedy series from Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane.

item.title: Wilko Johnson has cancer surgery
item.description: Former Dr Feelgood guitarist Wilko Johnson has a major operation in an attempt to treat his pancreatic cancer.

item.title: Government backs UK spaceport plan
item.description: The government backs plans for a UK spaceport and a huge expansion of the UK space industry, which it hopes can achieve a value of £40bn by 2030.

item.title: Warming boosts UK flooding risk
item.description: A citizen science project suggests climate change really has increased the risk of floods in the UK.

item.title: Drug resistance 'global threat'
item.description: Resistance to antibiotics poses a "major global threat" to public health, according to a report by the World Health Organization.

item.title: Fibre 'helps heart-attack survivors'
item.description: If you have had a heart attack, eat plenty of fibre because it may improve your long-term chances of recovery, say researchers.

item.title: Chelsea 1-3 Atletico Madrid (agg 1-3)
item.description: Atletico Madrid come from behind to beat Chelsea and set up a meeting with city rivals Real in the Champions League final.

item.title: Has wealth made Qatar happy?
item.description: Oil and gas have made Qatar the world's richest country, per head of population - but there is a sense that something important has been lost along the way.

item.title: How many middle-aged men need HRT?
item.description: Prescriptions for testosterone drugs are on the increase but there is growing concern that they are being over-used and may not be safe.

item.title: 'Child recruits' in South Sudan war
item.description: More than 9,000 child soldiers are fighting in South Sudan's brutal civil war as the country faces the threat of famine, the UN human rights chief says.

item.title: Modi accused of India poll violation
item.description: India's Election Commission accuses the main opposition BJP's prime ministerial candidate Narendra Modi of violating the election code.

item.title: Europe rejects UK financial tax case
item.description: Europe's top court rejects the UK's challenge to an EU financial transactions tax (FTT), which ministers have said will hurt British firms and savers.

item.title: Venezuela raises minimum wage by 30%
item.description: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announces a raise in the minimum wage and pensions of 30% ahead of the May Day celebrations.

item.title: UK urges swift Syria chlorine probe
item.description: The UK has called on the global chemical weapons watchdog to carry out "with urgency" its investigation into the alleged use of chlorine in Syria.

item.title: Two dead in Vancouver mill shooting
item.description: Two people have died and two are injured after a former employee opened fire at a Vancouver-area lumber mill.

item.title: Boy charged with teacher's murder
item.description: A 15-year-old boy is charged with the murder of a teacher who was stabbed at a school in Leeds.

item.title: Stop and search to be overhauled
item.description: A new code of practice for police stop and searches is to be introduced, the home secretary says, with the aim of cutting the number carried out.

item.title: Care home CCTV 'could be considered'
item.description: There "could be a role" for CCTV in care homes, Care Minister Norman Lamb says after an undercover BBC Panorama investigation finds residents of one being mistreated.

item.title: Farage will not stand in by-election
item.description: UKIP leader Nigel Farage says he will not stand in a by-election caused by the resignation of former Tory MP Patrick Mercer.

item.title: In pictures: Bob Hoskins
item.description: Pictures from the life and career of Bob Hoskins who has died aged 71

item.title: In pictures: Fatal teacher stabbing
item.description: Community in shock after stabbing of Ann Maguire

item.title: In pictures: US deadly tornadoes
item.description: Storm system sweeps across the central and southern US

item.title: Week in pictures: 19-25 April 2014
item.description: News photos from the past week

item.title: Day in pictures: 29 April 2014
item.description: News photos from past 24 hours: 29 April

item.title: In pictures: Anzac Day
item.description: Remember those who fought and died for their countries

item.title: Day in pictures: 28 April 2014
item.description: News photos from past 24 hours: 28 April

item.title: In pictures: Assault on Sloviansk
item.description: Operation against pro-Russian separatists

item.title: The man with 42 hours to get home
item.description: A man who is always travelling - and always rushing home

item.title: VIDEO: New York's Sherpas on life after Everest
item.description: Sherpas on life after Mount Everest

item.title: 'Africa's Che Guevara': Thomas Sankara's legacy
item.description: West African hero Thomas Sankara's legacy lives on

item.title: In pictures: Desperate plight of Muslims in Myanmar camp
item.description: Myanmar's displaced Muslims fight to survive

item.title: Azraq: How a refugee camp is built from scratch
item.description: What goes into designing a refugee camp in the desert?

item.title: Day in pictures: 30 April 2014
item.description: Striking news photos from around the world

item.title: Is this the most boring advert ever made?
item.description: Why is this camera advert 45 minutes long?

item.title: VIDEO: Too sexy for Kenya's police?
item.description: Kenya policewoman wins Twitter support after skirt reprimand

item.title: Why spy posters are all over Islamabad
item.description: Why spy posters are all over Islamabad

item.title: Beaten in India for 'drinking beer'
item.description: Beaten for 'drinking beer and peeing in the Ganges'

item.title: China to overtake US as world's largest economy?
item.description: Is China about to overtake US as world's largest economy?

item.title: Narendra Modi's clever election pitch in Gujarat
item.description: Narendra Modi's clever election pitch in Gujarat

item.title: Are conservatives deserting Sarah Palin?
item.description: Are conservatives now deserting Sarah Palin?
